Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Mechanisms Driving Atmospheric River Variability--An Investigation Using High Resolution Global Climate Model Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will examine heavy precipitation events in the western United States known as atmospheric rivers. The predictability and variability of these events will be characterized in high-resolution global climate model output with reanalysis and observations used to characterize model biases. The goals are to (i) characterize the climatology and natural variability of these storms frequencies and strength in observations, reanalysis, and high-resolution model simulations using various detection algorithms; (ii) analyze the predictability of such events using hindcast simulations and identifying atmospheric and oceanic conditions in which these events develop and are suppressed; and (iii) combine the knowledge gained above to utilize high-resolution global model simulations to examine changes in atmospheric rivers in the future and test the robustness of classifications and predictions made using the present climate. This project has high broader impacts as it will shed insights into extreme precipitation events in western US, specifically California

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Summary

This project was developed to examine atmospheric river (AR) storm variability in high-resolution global climate model simulations and their influence on the land surface. High-resolution global climate models break the globe up in a larger number of grid points than low-resolution models, resulting in high mountains located where mountains actually exist, instead of low rolling hills that are the byproduct of averaging elevations over larger areas for fewer grid points in low-resolution models. In many water basins, ARs act like the region’s hurricanes by being the main source of heavy precipitation events and flooding. In some regions, including the west coast of the United States, ARs can also contribute a majority of the annual precipitation. During the course of the fellowship, an algorithm has been under development to detect these storms globally at any time, much like algorithms exist to detect hurricanes globally. The logic for this was to have a way to monitor storms as they move across ocean basins and make landfall. It is important to track them over entire ocean basins as different conditions can lead to storms being more prevalent or intense in different locations. Previously available detection algorithms from other studies were developed for ARs making landfall at specific coasts, states, or countries. The Principal Investigator (PI) identified this as an issue when first trying to optimize a regionally developed algorithm to detect storms across model configurations as models can have unique prevalent circulation patterns that placed storms in different locations outside the smaller regional detection zones. In trying to test and validate global climate model fidelity for representing these storms, it is therefore important to track all storms to identify potential impacts of biases in atmospheric circulation on storm location and strength.

During the development of the tracking algorithm, the PI also examined United States land-based measurements of precipitation using precipitation gauges and snow stations. Since atmospheric rivers represent major precipitation and snowfall events, precipitation and snowfall biases in the model can reveal that storms are too weak or infrequent. In this analysis, it was found that the high-resolution global climate models at the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory capture snowpack (amount of snow on the ground) climatology as measured by mean February through April snow water equivalent. Using a suite of different model configurations (the PI chose to mainly alter resolution, which varies the height and complexity of mountains), the highest resolution models were also found to have some predictive skill for predicting winter snowpack several months in advance in extreme years. This suggests that the model is representing the correct amount of precipitation coming from large-scale storms like ARs during the cold fall and winter months.

 

Broader Impacts

This project also had several broader impacts. The PI collaborated on a published interdisciplinary study using the model output looking at climate impacts of precipitation and temperature. She was also involved in several outreach activities, including serving as an expert scientist to the Fish and Wildlife Service and speaking at the World Science Festival. The PI also developed a program (Princeton Women in Geosciences Initiative) at Princeton University for developing and retaining early career scientists, particularly women, in Geosciences.
